snippet: Interviews with former BBC officials suggest that Mark Thompson and his top executives repeatedly missed opportunities to pursue a fuller picture of the BBC’s investigation into Jimmy Savile.
abstract: Interviews with former BBC officials suggest that former director general Mark Thompson and his top executives repeatedly missed opportunities to pursue fuller picture of BBC’s investigation into decades-old accusations of child sexual abuse against longtime host Jimmy Savile; events have forced Thompson's new boss, New York Times publisher and chairman Arthur Sulzberger Jr, to defend him even before he starts work as president and chief executive.

byline.contributor: Christine Haughney contributed reporting from New York and Lark Turner contributed research from London.

lead_paragraph: Interviews with former BBC officials suggest that Mark Thompson and his top executives repeatedly missed opportunities to pursue a fuller picture of the BBC’s investigation into Jimmy Savile.

headline.seo: Mark Thompson and BBC Missed Red Flags in Savile Scandal
headline.main: As Scandal Flared, BBC’s Leaders Missed Red Flags
